talks.title: Modern Python packaging
talks.speaker: Aarni Koskela
talks.description: Still using setup.py and requirements.txt for your library or application? You probably shouldn't be! A small tour and opinionated talk on newer (and arguably better) alternatives.

talks.title: Debugging Python
talks.speaker: Juha-Matti Santala
talks.description: Debugging can be a stressful experience to a developer. In this talk, I provide practical and hands-on tips both for dealing both with the mental side and the technical tools and approaches that can help Python developers turn stressful debugging situations into joyful experiences.

special.name: Testing Sprint
special.description: Our first sprint in February was focused around polishing our skills in writing tests.

talks.title: Good-enough SRE for production software projects
talks.speaker: Magdalena Stenius
talks.description: During the past couple of years, SRE seems to have become the new hype-word of engineering. In this talk I’ll walk you through some of the basic themes of it and a practical example of good-enough SRE practices for Wolts personalisation-api service, the central service for multiple models catering to our global user base every day.

talks.title: Implementing and using Rule-based systems in Python
talks.speaker: Mikko Harju
talks.description: In this talk, we will explore what rule-based systems are, how to use the py-rete as the foundation to create your own rule-based systems and extend the syntax a bit to aid simpler definition of specific rules.

special.name: Web Dev Sprint
special.description: Our second sprint focused on web development tools like Django, Flask and FastAPI.

talks.title: Vector Embeddings: Clustering, Recommendations, and Visualization in Python
talks.speaker: Robert Siipola

talks.title: Building web-APIs with Python
talks.speaker: Calle Laakkonen
talks.description: A quick introduction to building REST and GraphQL APIs using different frameworks to suit all occasions, from simple minimalistic utilities to big web applications.

talks.title: Deep dive into Python generators
talks.speaker: Janne Rönkkö
talks.description: Generators can be found pretty much every Python project -- you might be using those without realizing it. In this talk we will explore what Python's generators are, how they work, their pitfalls and how you can utilize those in your own projects.

talks.title: Let’s be BFFs <3
talks.speaker: Mila Grigoryeva
talks.description: Let’s look into a web development design pattern called BFF - Backend for Frontend. In this talk, I will walk you through the main concepts as well as share both pros and cons of using such a design pattern in your web system.

special.name: Advent of Code Sprint
special.description: In December we got together to solve Advent of Code puzzles together at Konttori.

talks.title: Python notebooks and version controlling
talks.speaker: Ilkka Vuorio
talks.description: Notebooks are the wrong tool for so many problems, but they do wonders for others. But how do you version-control them without losing it?

talks.title: Meson: a build system in and for Python
talks.speaker: Jussi Pakkanen
talks.description: Meson is a build system for compiled languages like C, C++ and Rust that has been designed from the ground up for usability. In this presentation we look how it can be used to build a cross platform project that is then exposed to Python and even uploaded to PyPI. Jussi Pakkanen is the creator and current project lead of Meson. He has worked on software projects ranging from data analysis to the Linux desktop, embedded development and multimedia frameworks. He is currently enjoying a sabbatical year.

talks.title: Lightning talk: Python news!
talks.speaker: Hugo van Kemenade
talks.description: Hugo will share some news from the Python ecosystem in a lightning talk!

special.name: Sprint
special.description: In February, we got together to work on our own projects.

talks.title: Let's build an overengineered LLM pipeline
talks.speaker: Juho Ylikylä
talks.description: Overengineering is fun but not safe for work. Since we are off the clock, let's go wild and use select hyped open-source Python generative AI libraries and build a thing.

talks.title: Contemporary Documentation
talks.speaker: Juha-Matti Santala
talks.description: Teams change often. People leave and people join. In addition to those changes, we tend to forget what we were thinking. That's why it's a good practice to document those thoughts, discussions and decisions into a format that doesn't lose them. In this talk I explore ways to use tools and processes you might be familiar with - version control and project management tools - to help you document the motivation, thoughts and intents behind changes when they happen. You'll get practical tips that you can take back to your work the next day.

talks.title: Lightning talk: Single-file executable scripts with uv
talks.speaker: Tero Ykspetäjä

talks.title: Lightning talk: PyO3 uniting Python and Rust
talks.speaker: Aarni Koskela

special.name: Sprint
special.description: In April, we got together to work on our own projects.

talks.title: Locale codes for fun and profit
talks.speaker: Eemeli Aro
talks.description: Languages on the internet are identified by locale codes: fi, es-419, zh-Hant, and many more. Let me show you why these matter more than you think, take you down some of their less familiar pathways, and share some of the work we're doing in defining a few that don't quite exist yet, like en-ZZ and zxx.

talks.title: Type safe data validation with Pydantic
talks.speaker: Calle Laakkonen
talks.description: Motivation: why do we want to validate our input data in the first place Quick intro to Python type hints Pydantic for data validation and examples

talks.title: Lightning talk: PyCon Finland
talks.speaker: Asko Soukka

talks.title: Lightning talk: typtyp: Generate TypeScript types from Python code
talks.speaker: Aarni Koskela

talks.title: How Would You Test This? The Python Edition
talks.speaker: Maaret Pyhäjärvi
talks.description: With generative AI in application testing, I see a repeated unhelpful agent message: insert specifications to generate test cases. It's now more important than ever to get this: test cases are not testing. Testing is the process of empirical research for information we might be missing. Test cases can be an input (as the traditional framing of it goes) or they can be an output (as the exploratory framing of it goes). I recommend they are code - and I demo this idea primarily in Python code. In this session, we take a single page application and ask: how would you test this? With notes, programmatic tests in python, a listing of now known bugs, we will see how testing actually works, and why in age of AI the 'human in the loop' or 'alignment engineer' would do well with solid testing skills. And it does not hurt that those very same solid testing skills are valued in developers in the current market.

talks.title: Python is great for quick prototyping
talks.speaker: Juha-Matti Santala
talks.description: This summer, I got to build a prototype to demo a design concept. In two weeks, I took it from an idea to live demo at Helsinki Design Week using Python, Flask, IKEA DIRIGERA and Telegram integration. I'll share what I built and how I approached prototyping such a limited scope and schedule project.

talks.title: Is keyword search dead?
talks.speaker: Niklas Nevalainen
talks.description: Search powers many of the AI systems built today yet it's often treated as an afterthought. In this talk I'll break down how keyword and vector searches differ, and show how these perform in an Elasticsearch demo. We'll also take a look at what happens when you mix the two. This talk is about inverted indices, relevance, signals, hobbits, and perhaps some learnings as well.

talks.title: States, Events, Action!
talks.speaker: Stephen Sullivan
talks.description: An example of building a 'event driven finite state machine' in Python. We'll cover: Why implementing a soluton from an existing pattern can be a good idea The finite state machine as a pattern for bringing order to chaos A walkthrough of coding one in Python. A practical talk aimed at both early career developers and those who like arguing about abstractions.

talks.title: Lightning talk: Python 3.14 news
talks.speaker: Hugo van Kemenade

talks.title: Lightning talk: Profiling Python code using Viztracer
talks.speaker: Aarni Koskela

special.name: Advent of Code Sprint
special.description: We got together to solve Advent of Code puzzles, learn programming and catch up before the holidays.
